Situation1: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Story: I sat on the couch, phone in hand, glancing at the clock. My partner slumped beside me, eyes red, shoulders hunched. He’d just told me about the harsh feedback he got at work, and I could feel the weight of his disappointment filling the room. I wanted to reach out, hold his hand, tell him I was here for him, that he was more than his job. But my phone buzzed with reminders—my sales numbers were soaring this week, and my manager had just sent a message: “Keep up the momentum! Every call counts.” I knew if I kept pushing, I could finally be top of the leaderboard, maybe even get that bonus. But every minute I spent dialing was a minute I wasn’t there for him. My heart twisted as I watched him stare at the floor, needing comfort, while my fingers itched to make the next call. I felt torn, the pressure from work and the ache to be a good girlfriend pulling me in opposite directions, and I didn’t know which voice to listen to.
